div1.ab: Consulate of the United States at Bathurst 11th August 1859
div1.p: Sir; I have the honor to en- -close herewith The Secretary No.1 Return of Arrivals + Departures of American vessels for the Quarter ending the 30th of June last also the Quarterly Return of No.2 Fees for the lame period amount- ing to sixty two dollars and fifty six cents.

You will also find here- No.3 -with a copy of the Treaty between France and England relative to Portendia and Albreda, and the free navigation of the Gambia, con- ceded to France by the latter pow- er.
I have indirectly learned that Her Majesty's Government has sent a Despatch to the
div1.ab: Honorable Lewis Cap Secretary of State of the United States Washington
div1.p: Acting Governor of the settlement the Contents of which are to this purpose, that, the House Govern- ment experienced many difficul- ties in regard to the right of free navigation of the Gambia accorded to the French, form which the Powers with whom England has treaties with the "most favored nation" Lause; that it could be agreeable to the House Govern- ment to have the opening of the river to the whole world made the subject of a petition from the Colonists.

I am inclined to believe that the Colonists, particularly the Com- mercial part of the community are opposed to this , as they also were to the opening of the River to the French. and not to little purpose.
The advantages to the desired from the force navigations of the Gambia, as far as the United- States are concerned are at
present, perhaps, important But I am convinced that the future will tend to increase those advantages.

The river is navigable to ves- sels drawing not more than eight feet of conter as far as Me' Calhip Island the principal British settlement, and about two hundred miles above this. The puncipal articles of pro- duce procured in the River are Governed Weeks (Peamoks), of which the animal export for the past year was 15728 tons requiring a considerable amount of shipping to bring these here to market. About 70,000 hides and 100 tons of Beeswax exported in the lame period of time.
This carrying trade is now per- pound by British vessels almost entirely, Most of the French vessels being too large or dread- ing too much waken to ascend
the river to any distance. American vessels from their perticularly flat build and large deer capacity are better adapted than either British or French for this carrying trade.

The British trade as at present carried on is not a rely profitable one. There are Eight English + three French Houses enfafed in it from this port. Perces obtained for goods, in the River, are large and remu= wershice, but the disadvantages and lopes aside 1st. From employing native Mandingors (in whose language there appoars to be no such word as honesty) for traders. I From the of small vessels required to bring the produce to town, the expense of which, increases very considerably the price of the produce.
It has occured to me that this matter would be worthy the con- -sideration of the United States
and that perhaps the present would be favorable moment for bringing it before Her Majesty's Goverment.

Should it be the wish of the Depart- -ment I should be of ad upon the return of the healthy season commencing in November or December to ascend the River as far as Mo' Caithy Island and make a report thereon.

I regret that my present state of health requires a chance of climate and ascending to the order of my medical man I shall be obligd to leave my Con- -suate for the coming two months and proceed to the Island of Seneieffe.
I have appointed Mr. Richard Charles Lloyd Acting Consul during my absence. I have the honor to be Sir, Your most obident servant Daniel R.B. Upton United States Consul
